comments.body: I don't believe this is correct. `args` and `kwargs` need to be passed to class when it is instantiated. This should probably be `*args, **kwargs`, though.
I know this is what it done in `load_platform_subclass()` but that looks incorrect as well.
Some tests were failing complaining about this.

```/ansible_user_payload_r6aajx5l/ansible_user_payload.zip/ansible/modules/system/user.py", line 2989, in <module>
  File "/tmp/ansible_user_payload_r6aajx5l/ansible_user_payload.zip/ansible/modules/system/user.py", line 2877, in main
  File "/tmp/ansible_user_payload_r6aajx5l/ansible_user_payload.zip/ansible/modules/system/user.py", line 463, in __new__
TypeError: object.__new__() takes exactly one argument (the type to instantiate)
",```
I'll have to look into this more. I'll find out more tomorrow when the author gets back from PTO.

Alright, after a deep dive into what `__new__()` is actually doing, this change is correct.

`__new__()` happens before `__init__()` and simply returns the instantiated but not initialized object. `args, kwargs` would be passed to `__new__()` in order to affect the object selection logic. They would not affect object initialization.

Since they are not used by our `__new__()` method, they can be omitted from the `super().__new_()` call.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +138,142 @@            def __new__(cls, *args, **kwargs):
                new_cls = get_platform_subclass(User)
                return super(cls, new_cls).__new__(new_cls)
    '''
